string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.

slidelink.displaytext: What do you already know about purchasing an investment property?
Research the area and identify potential properties
Determine common rental rates and potential profit margin.
Review local and state requirements for residential rental properties
Evaluating tenants, security deposit and tenant documents.

search.slidetext: real investing buying a residential investment property

before we begin, let’s make sure this is the right module for you. land/acreage commercial residential agricultural or residential properties that have not been developed, and farms are often listed in this category. commercial properties are zoned and designed for business operations such as hair salons, liquor stores and office space. residential properties are typically leased to individuals or families to house them. point to your preferred type of investment property.

this module will introduce or strengthen your understanding of issues you must consider when purchasing a residential investment property. land/acreage commercial commercial properties are zoned and designed for business operations such as hair salons, liquor stores and office space. agricultural or residential properties that have not been developed, and farms are often listed in this category. residential residential properties are typically leased to individuals or families to house them.

20% is correct. because the home purchase is being made for an investment and will not be owner-occupied for at least 2 years before being converted into a rental property, most banks require 20% down. additionally, pmi is not available. pmi which stands for private mortgage insurance, is not available to buyers of investment properties. 20% 20% 20% correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue 20% 20% 20% 30% 30% 30% drag the correct puzzle piece to finish the puzzle. what is the typical down payment required by a mortgage company? what do you already know about purchasing an investment property?

false false is correct. you will be required to purchase homeowner’s insurance for a rental property to insure the structure itself, not the contents. this protects the bank’s investment. most landlords requiretheir tenants to have renter’s insurance in order to protect their own possessions. true or false: your homeowner’s insurance will cover furnishings and possessions in your investment property. what do you already know about purchasing an investment property? false drag the correct puzzle piece to finish the puzzle.

residential investing research the area and identify potential properties review insurance and lease requirements evaluating tenants, security deposit and tenant documents. review local and state requirements for residential rental properties negotiate with mortgage lenders navigate to your desired topics by clicking each letter below. to return to this page, click the key image on any slide. determine common rental rates and potential profit margin

residential investing research the area and identify potential properties review insurance and lease requirements evaluating tenants, security deposit and tenant documents. review local and state requirements for residential rental properties negotiate with mortgage lenders navigate to your desired topics by clicking each letter below. to return to this page, click the key image on any slide. determine common rental rates and potential profit margin exit exit exit exit exit exit

how can you learn about the area before you contact a realtor? online crime maps speak to neighbors property characteristics? type of property? visit the property at different times of day. conduct a real property search social media/neighborhood groups realtors are limited in what they can tell you about a neighborhood and the people who live there. they are also not allowed to affirm the crime rate or school district. do your own research. what characteristics of the area are important to you (and your future tenants)? great school district low crime rate walkability public transportation type of property? learn area? property characteristics? what type of property are you looking for? single family multi-family condo a multi-family home that has two or more units in the same building, typically sharing a common wall. a free-standing, single unit residential building a residential unit in a building or complex comprised of other residential units. typically involves central entrance and fees for shared spaces. duplex a home that has only two units in the same building, typically sharing a common wall. purchaser is buying one unit. learn area? what type of property are you looking for? what characteristics of the area are important to you (and your future tenants)? how can you learn about the area before you contact a realtor? research the area and identify types of potential properties what kind of property are you looking for? what characteristics of the area are important to you (and your future tenants)? how can you learn about the area before you contact a realtor?

determine common rental rates and potential profit margin. identify characteristics of the home research rents for comparable properties research rents for comparable properties check social media for “for rent” of other properties. speak to a realtor to run comparative rental report. research rents for comparable properties how much income can your property produce monthly? click the resources link to see a sample spreadsheet to calculate potential profit margin. number of bedrooms number of bathrooms laundry (on-site) off-street parking yard overall condition curb appeal

rental properties used for short term vacation rentals such as airbnb may have other fees and requirements. rental properties used for short term vacation rentals such as airbnb may have other fees and requirements. fees may be levied by the county, town, village or home owner’s association. inspections may include lead paint, carbon monoxide and smoke detectors among others. inspections may include lead paint, carbon monoxide and smoke detectors among others. some jurisdictions, such as baltimore county in maryland, only allow 2 unrelated adults to rent a single dwelling. review local and state requirements for residential rental properties # of unrelated occupants licensing/ registration fees inspections term of lease regulations require non-discriminatory practice. some adult communities have an age threshold for residents. non-discrimination regulations

a rate lock is an assurance from the lender that the interest rate you have selected will be honored for a specific period of time, even if interest rates change in the market. a rate can usually be locked for no more than 30-60 days. points and fees refer to money paid to the lender to secure a reduced interest rate for the loan. they are usually a percentage of the loan amount. for example: on a $500,000 loan, one point would typically cost 1%, so $5000 in order to reduce the interest rate of the loan .25%. over a 30 year mortgage that .25% could translate to a savings of $30,000 over the life of the loan. investment property interest rates are usually at least 0.5% to 0.75% higher than standard rates. so if the average rate is 3.49% (3.523% apr) for a primary residence, buyers can expect interest rates to start around 3.99% to 4.24% (4.023 – 4.273% apr) for a single–unit investment property. negotiate with mortgage lenders interest rate points/fees rate lock lenders will ask you to provide: address of the property permission to pull your credit amount of your downpayment a list of your current financial obligations (car payments, other mortgage, loan payments, etc.) your income when shopping for mortgage rates, your credit will not be impacted even if your credit report is pulled by multiple financial institutions, as long as it is within 45 days. you should ask: current interest rate and loan terms what points/fees/costs are associated with the loan how long you can lock your interest rate any discounts available to you you must: shop different lenders and get at least 3 quotes make lenders compete for your business get quotes in writing get pre-approved for a mortgage before shopping for properties

review insurance and lease requirements homeowner’s insurance for rental properties typically does not cover: fireplaces or woodstoves certain dog breeds tenant possessions and furnishings lease/rental agreements vary in different counties and states. research appropriate leases for the jurisdiction of the property. see resources link for a sample lease. $ $ $

evaluating tenants, security deposit and tenant documents. lease/rental agreements vary in different counties and states. research appropriate leases for the jurisdiction of the property. a lease may include details such as: term - month to month vs 12 month contracting parties must be legal adults must include liability issues amount of security deposit requirement for renter’s insurance pet policy sub-lease restrictions maximum number of occupants tenant rights and responsibilities – uninterrupted enjoyment, renewal option, termination process consider using a tenantscreening service such asturbotenant, smartmove or others to perform a background check and income verification for each tenant over the age of eighteen.

slide graphics by slidesgo and freepik for further information contact brandon yerrid brandonyerrid@kw.com 443-474-1037 443-574-1600 end module end module end module end module end module end module return to module return to module return to module return to module return to module return to module

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: <Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Income-producing real estate properties are within reach of many people. The secret is to arm yourself with good information, ask good questions and work with an exceptional realtor. This module will help you address all of these. On the left of your screen, you can see a table of contents. Use that if you want to skip to a particular topic. On most slides you will see a next button, highlighted here. Click the Next button to proceed to the next slide and let’s get started." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="While both commercial properties and land can yield income, this module will focus on the purchase of residential properties. Residential properties are located in areas zoned for residential use to house individuals and families." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Let’s see what you already know about purchasing an investment property. Answer the question by dragging the correct piece onto the puzzle." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="True or False: Your homeowner’s insurance will cover furnishings and possessions in your investment property. Drag the correct puzzle piece to finish the puzzle.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="False is correct. You may be surprised to learn that, unlike homeowner’s insurance that you purchase for your personal residence, insurance purchased for a rental property does not cover the contents of the property." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Investing in real estate involves a variety of steps, resources and requirements. While we cannot cover everything that may influence your purchase and rental process, we’d like to share some information that is common to these transactions. Click the letter to view the associated step in the investment purchase process. To return to this screen at any time, click the Key image." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Investing in real estate involves a variety of steps, resources and requirements. While we cannot cover everything that may influence your purchase and rental process, we’d like to share some information that is common to these transactions. Click the letter to view the associated step in the investment purchase process. To return to this screen at any time, click the Key image." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Residential properties come in a variety of styles and in many disparate locations. Will your property be nestled in a quiet cul-de-sac, or is it close to a major highway? Is it on the bus route or within walking distance of shops and services? And what about the crime rate? Click each option to learn more as you consider various types of properties and how you can learn more about them.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Consider your prospective tenants and what characteristics they may value in a home. Most would identify quality schools and safety as essential, but some may require access to public transportation or the ability to walk to recreation, shopping and services.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Realtors can provide you with the history of a property and its current market value but there are laws that limit what else they may be able to tell you about a property or neighborhood. You can still learn a lot by doing your own research. Consider joining a neighborhood group on social media to ask about the area. Visit the property at different times of day and on different days of the week. What’s the traffic and noise level? Take a look at a free online map of reported crimes in the area to help you evaluate overall safety. Speak to any neighbors who are out and about and finally, consider using the Maryland Real Property Database to search for more detailed information about a property." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="While it’s a common fantasy to own a home in the mountains and one at the beach, in this case you are pursuing a property for the income it can generate. You’ll have to evaluate the property, it’s market value and the going rates for rental units as you make your decision to purchase. Point to each image to learn more. We have provided an Excel spreadsheet in the Resources section of this module, for you to evaluate your own property and potential profits." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Owning a rental property means adhering to the various legal requirements of the area in which the property is located. There can be differences in regulations between states, counties, and even neighborhoods if a home owners association is involved. Point to each image on the slide to learn more." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Securing a mortgage for an investment property takes time, effort and negotiation skills. Potential lenders will ask you for a significant amount of financial information so that they can qualify you for a mortgage, even if you opt not to use their firm. And you might not choose to use the first mortgage broker you speak to, or the second, even if they are associated with other financial institutions with whom you have a relationship, like your bank or credit union. As the customer, you should be asking a significant number of questions and price shopping for the best deal. Don’t be afraid to tell one lender about the great interest rate being offered by a different lender. They may be able to beat it or at least reduce your points. To learn more about points, interest and rate locks, point to each image on the slide." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="You may be surprised to learn that homeowner’s insurance has different requirements and coverage if the home you are insuring is not owner-occupied. Insurance companies, in an effort to limit their financial liability, often will not insure your rental property if it has a wood burning stove or fireplace, or is being rented to people with certain breeds of dogs such as pit bulls. Your homeowner’s insurance is to protect the bank from loss and does not include insuring your tenant’s belongings.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Your lease agreement should likely include a clause that requires your tenant to purchase renter’s insurance. There are many different types of leases but their goal is to create a clear set of expectations, in the form of a legally binding contract, between you and your tenants. See the resources link in this module for a sample lease." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Thank you for viewing this module and we hope that the information we’ve shared has given you some useful background about the purchase process for residential real estate. If you would like to speak to a realtor, please contact Brandon Yerrid of Keller Williams." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
